_prev_prog_3.Description: The West Wilson Utility District Water Plant has identified the amount of Chlorine onsite exceeds the Threshold Quanity of 1,500 pounds as listed in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119 - List of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, Toxics and Reactives.   The Process Safety Management plan includes the following:                                                                                                                 1. A written plan of action for implementing employee consultation on the development of process hazard analyses and other elements of process hazard management contained within 1910.119.                                                  2. Compiled written process safety information on process chemical chlorine, process technology, and process equipment before conducting the process hazard analysis.                                                                                                     3. Developed a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating and controlling processes involving chlorine.                                       4. Developed operating procedures addressing steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.                                                                                                5. Developed an effective training program that helps employees and contractor employees understand the nature and causes of problems arising from process operations, which increases employee awareness with respect to the hazards particular to the chlorine process.                                                      6. Developed a screening process so that they hire and use contractors who accomplish the desired job tasks without compromising the safety and health of employees at the facility                                                                                                                    7. Developed a Pre-startup safety review that addresses the following:  construction and equipment is in accordance with the design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate, employee training, and meet the requirements for management of change.                                                                                                                  8. Developed a mechanical integrity program to assure the continued integrity of process equipment.  The mechanical integrity program includes the identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation, development of written maintenance procedures, training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, correction of deficiencies in equipment that are outside acceptable limits defined by the process safety information, and development of a quality assurance program.                           9. Establish requirements that control, in a consistent manner, nonroutine work conducted in process areas.  Specifically, these requirements focus on the permitting of hot work operations associated with welding and cutting in process areas.                                                                                                        10. Developed written procedures to manage change; addressing the technical basis, impact on safety and health, modification to operating procedures, necessary time period, and authorizations required; informing and training employees affects; and updating process safety information and operating procedures or practices.                                                                                        11. Developed procedures that  investigate each incident which resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace.                                                                                    12. Developed a plan that describes  what actions employees are to take when there is an unwanted release of highly hazardous chemicals.                               13. Developed protocols to perform self evaluations of the effectiveness of the PSM program by identifying deficiencies and assuring corrective actions.      14. Developed a policy that provides employees and their designated representatives access to all information without regards to possible trade secrets.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant is located in Wilson County at 399 Beth Dr. Mt. Juliet, Tennessee 37122.  The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant treats water from Old Hickory Lake which is part of the Cumberland River System for distribution to the public as potable water.  The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant uses chlorine in the treatment process as an oxidizing agent and a disinfectant. Chlorine is stored in the Chlorine Room in ton containers both as gas and as a pressurized liquid.  Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the ton containers and mixed with potable water with chlorinators which are also located in the Chlorine Room.  The chlorine/water solution is then piped to the application points, which include two influent pipes that supply eight filters, these pipes are located in the basement of the water treatment plant, and the mixing chamber located underneath the chlorine room.

Chlorine is identified as a regulated toxic substance Table 1 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 Subpart F.  West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant stores up to (six - one ton cylinders) 12,000 pounds of chorine on-site, which is more than the threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds (?40 CFR 68.130).  West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant has implemented a Risk Management Program for the chlorine process in accordance with the requirements of ?40 CFR 68.  The objective of the Risk Management Program is to identify the hazards that may result from accidental releases of chlorine, to ensure that the facility is designed and operated in a safe manner to prevent accidental releases of chlorine, and to minimize the consequences of any accidental releases which may occur. 

HAZARD ASSESSMENT

Worst-Case Release Scenario

The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant has evaluated a worst-case release scenario in accordance with the requirements of ?40 CRF 68.25.  EPA ha

s defined a worst-case release as, ?a release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.?  The release is assumed to occur instantaneously.  The possible causes of the release or the probability that such a release might occur is not considered in the worst-case scenario analysis; the release is simply assumed to take place.  

The toxic endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L as published in Appendix A to Part 68 ? Table of Toxic Endpoints.  The toxic endpoint is the maximum airborne concentration which is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serous health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual?s ability to take protective action.

The largest single storage vessel for chlorine at the West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant is 2000 pounds. For the worst-case scenario, it is assumed that the entire contents of the cylinder are released at ground level.  The chlorine is assumed to be released over a ten minute period.  The distance to the toxic endpoint of the impact area is estimated to be 1.3 miles, having an urban topography, as calculated by the RMP Comp software provided by EPA website.  The population within the impact area is estimated to be 2,959 persons.  Additionally, it is noted that schools, residences, recreational areas, and state wildlife management areas are located with in the impact area. 

The meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario are defined by EPA Guidance as atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere), wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour), and ambient air temperature of 25 degrees C.

Alternative Release Scenario

The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant has also evaluated an alternative release scenario in accordance with the requirements of ?40 CFR 68.28.  The alternative r

elease scenario selected is a vessel leak. The alternative release scenario is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario. However, written operating procedures are in place for the safe operation of the ton containers, and the probability of this type release is very low.  Employees are assumed to detect the release and stop the release using the Emergency ?B? Kit in one hour.  The release rate to the Chlorine Room is estimated to be fifteen pounds per minute.  This would result in a total quantity of nine hundred pounds of chlorine released. Since the chlorine is release inside the Chlorine Room and the building should have a mitigating effect on the release rate, it is assumed that the release rate to the atmosphere will be less than fifteen pounds per minute. It has been assumed that the release rate to the atmosphere will be fifty five percent of the release rate inside the building which is 15 pounds per minute.  This results in a release rate to the atmosphere of eight and on quarter pounds per minute.  The distance to the toxic endpoint is estimated to be two tenths of a mile as calculated by the RMPComp software provided by EPA website.  The population within the alternative release scenario impact area is estimated to be 127 persons.  There are no environmental receptors located within the impact area.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Throughout the life of the chlorine process at the West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant, there have been no accidental releases of chlorine that resulted in on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage. Also, there have been no accidental releases of chlorine at the facility that have resulted in off-site deaths, Injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant has implemented a prevention program in accordance with ?40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D and the Occupational Safety and Healt

its adequacy and compliance with the regulations.

EMERGENCY RESPONESE

The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant has developed and implemented an Emergency Response Plan for the purpose of protection its employees, public health, and the environment.  The Emergency Response Plan describes the emergency response to be followed during various potential emergency situations, including specific procedures for the responses to releases of chlorine.  The West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant has coordinated its Emergency Response Plan with the Wilson Emergency Management Agency to ensure that emergency responders and the public are aware of the potential hazards associated with the chlorine process. 

CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Although no significant accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at the facility, it is the policy of the West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant to continue to look for opportunities to improve on the safe handling and use of chlorine to minimize the risk to its employees and the community.  Implementation of a Risk Management Program (in accordance with ?40 CFR Part 68 and a Process Safety Management Program (in accordance with ?29 CFR 1910.119 are two steps that the West Wilson Utility District Water Treatment Plant have taken to ensure safe operation of the chlorine process.
